title: Hosea Chapter 8 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hosea chapter 8 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hosea Chapter 8 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hosea Chapter 8.

questions.question: According to Hosea 8:1, what instrument is set to the mouth as a warning?
questions.correctAnswer: Trumpet
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:1 says, 'Set the trumpet to thy mouth,' indicating the trumpet is the warning instrument.

questions.question: Who is described as coming against the house of the LORD in Hosea 8:1?
questions.correctAnswer: An eagle
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:1 states, 'He shall come as an eagle against the house of the LORD.'

questions.question: What does Israel cry unto God in Hosea 8:2?
questions.correctAnswer: My God, we know thee
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:2 records Israel's cry as 'My God, we know thee.'

questions.question: According to Hosea 8:3, what has Israel cast off?
questions.correctAnswer: The thing that is good
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:3 states, 'Israel hath cast off the thing that is good.'

questions.question: What have the people made from silver and gold according to Hosea 8:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Idols
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:4 says they made idols from silver and gold.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 8:5 says that the calf of Samaria has cast off the people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:5 states, 'Thy calf, O Samaria, hath cast thee off.'

questions.question: According to Hosea 8:6, who made the calf of Samaria?
questions.correctAnswer: The workman
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:6 states, 'the workman made it; therefore it is not God.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Hosea 8:7: 'For they have sown the ______, and they shall reap the whirlwind.'
questions.correctAnswer: wind
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:7 says, 'they have sown the wind, and they shall reap the whirlwind.'

questions.question: Who is Israel said to be among, according to Hosea 8:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The Gentiles
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:8 states, 'now shall they be among the Gentiles.'

questions.question: Hosea 8:9 compares Ephraim to what animal?
questions.correctAnswer: A wild ass
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:9 says, 'a wild ass alone by himself.'

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 8:11 says Ephraim made many altars to worship God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:11 says 'Ephraim hath made many altars to sin,' not to worship God.

questions.question: What did God write to Israel according to Hosea 8:12?
options: The great things of my law
questions.correctAnswer: The great things of my law
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:12 says, 'I have written to him the great things of my law.'

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 8:13 says the LORD accepted the sacrifices of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:13 states the LORD did not accept their sacrifices.

questions.question: According to Hosea 8:13, where shall Israel return because of their sins?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:13 says, 'they shall return to Egypt.'

questions.question: According to Hosea 8:14, what will God send upon the cities?
questions.correctAnswer: A fire
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:14 says, 'I will send a fire upon his cities.'

medium.title: Hosea Chapter 8 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hosea Chapter 8 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of abandonment by God due to consequences of sin. Based on Hosea 8, what biblical truth would you share about God's response to covenant breaking?
options: God will come as an eagle against those who transgress His covenant
God will ignore their cries for help
God will immediately forgive without any discipline
questions.correctAnswer: God will come as an eagle against those who transgress His covenant
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:1 states that the Lord will come as an eagle against His house because they have transgressed His covenant, illustrating that God disciplines sin but is aware of the breach. This shows God's justice in response to covenant breaking (Hosea 8:1, 8:3, 8:13).

questions.question: How does Hosea 8 teach us about the danger of trusting in idols instead of God in our daily lives?
options: Idols made of silver and gold lead to destruction
Idols are acceptable as long as we pray
questions.correctAnswer: Idols made of silver and gold lead to destruction
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:4 warns that Israel made kings and princes from silver and gold idols, which will cause them to be cut off. This teaches the practical lesson that trusting in material idols leads to downfall, not security (Hosea 8:4, 8:6, 8:13).

questions.question: What biblical principle about consequences of sin can be learned from Hosea 8:7's statement "they have sown the wind, and they shall reap the whirlwind"?
options: Actions have greater consequences than expected
Good deeds always bring immediate reward
questions.correctAnswer: Actions have greater consequences than expected
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:7 uses this metaphor to show that Israel's sinful actions will result in even greater trouble. This teaches the practical truth that sin’s consequences often escalate, urging believers to persevere in righteousness (Hosea 8:7, 8:13, 8:14).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise integrity by following the crowd. How does Hosea 8:12 teach us about the value of God's law in resisting temptation?
options: God’s law contains great things that guide us, even if considered strange
God’s law is outdated and irrelevant
questions.correctAnswer: God’s law contains great things that guide us, even if considered strange
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:12 highlights that God wrote great things in His law for Israel, though they treated it as strange. This encourages believers to value and obey God’s Word for strength to resist temptation (Hosea 8:12, 8:13, 8:14).

questions.question: How does Hosea 8:13 teach about the importance of sincere worship and obedience rather than mere rituals?
options: God does not accept sacrifices without true obedience
Rituals are more important than obedience
God only cares about external actions
questions.correctAnswer: God does not accept sacrifices without true obedience
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:13 states that although Israel sacrificed flesh, the Lord did not accept it and will remember their sins. This teaches the practical lesson that worship must be accompanied by obedience and sincerity (Hosea 8:13, 8:11, 8:14).

questions.question: A Christian is discouraged by the consequences of their past sins. What hope or warning does Hosea 8 provide about returning to old sinful patterns?
options: Returning to sin leads to sorrow and being swallowed up among the nations
God will forget all sins instantly without repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Returning to sin leads to sorrow and being swallowed up among the nations
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:8-10 warns that Israel will be swallowed up among the Gentiles and will sorrow for the burden of their leaders because of their sin. This teaches that returning to sin has serious consequences and calls for repentance (Hosea 8:8-10, 8:13).

questions.question: According to Hosea 8, how should believers view political or worldly leaders who are not established by God?
options: Leadership not ordained by God can lead to idolatry and downfall
All political leaders are appointed by God and infallible
Believers should blindly follow all leaders
Worldly leadership has no spiritual consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Leadership not ordained by God can lead to idolatry and downfall
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:4 points out that Israel set up kings without God’s approval, made from silver and gold idols, which leads to destruction. This teaches the importance of trusting God’s guidance in leadership (Hosea 8:4, 8:5).

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 8 teaches that God is patient and will never punish His people for their sins.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:1 and 8:14 clearly show God's anger and judgment against Israel for their sin and idolatry, including sending fire upon their cities. This demonstrates that God disciplines sin, not ignoring it.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 8:9 compares Ephraim to a wild ass alone, illustrating the folly of seeking alliances apart from God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:9 uses the image of a wild ass alone to describe Ephraim’s foolishness in seeking help from Assyria rather than trusting God, teaching reliance on God rather than worldly alliances.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hosea 8:6 teaches that the calf of Samaria is not God because it was made by the ______.
questions.correctAnswer: workman
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:6 states the calf was made by the workman, not God, emphasizing that idols are man-made and false, teaching believers to worship the true God.

questions.question: How does Hosea 8:5-6 warn believers about trusting in false security symbols like idols?
options: Idols will be broken in pieces and cannot provide true security
questions.correctAnswer: Idols will be broken in pieces and cannot provide true security
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:5-6 declares the calf of Samaria, an idol, will be broken in pieces, showing that false security in idols leads to destruction rather than safety.

questions.question: A believer is feeling spiritually dry and questions if their efforts to live rightly matter. How does Hosea 8:7's imagery encourage perseverance?
options: Sowing the wind results in reaping the whirlwind, so sin leads to greater trouble, urging us to persist in good deeds
Efforts are futile and should be abandoned
questions.correctAnswer: Sowing the wind results in reaping the whirlwind, so sin leads to greater trouble, urging us to persist in good deeds
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:7 warns of escalating consequences for sin, encouraging believers to persevere in obedience and avoid sowing 'wind' that yields a 'whirlwind.'

questions.question: What does Hosea 8:14 teach about God’s discipline concerning those who forget their Maker and rely on human strength?
options: God will send fire to devour their cities and palaces
God will immediately restore them without correction
questions.correctAnswer: God will send fire to devour their cities and palaces
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:14 warns that forgetting God and trusting in human means leads to divine judgment, symbolized by fire consuming their cities, teaching the importance of remembering and trusting God.

questions.question: How does Hosea 8:11 apply to church life and personal holiness?
options: Making many altars to sin brings ongoing sin and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Making many altars to sin brings ongoing sin and judgment
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:11 says Ephraim made many altars to sin, indicating that multiplying sinful practices leads to persistent sin, urging believers to pursue holiness in church and life.

questions.question: According to Hosea 8:3, what happens when a nation or believer casts off what is good?
questions.correctAnswer: The enemy pursues them
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:3 states that Israel cast off what is good and as a result, the enemy pursues him, showing the practical consequence of rejecting God's good ways.

hard.title: Hosea Chapter 8 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hosea Chapter 8.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'trumpet' mentioned in Hosea 8:1 within the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It signals a call to battle or warning of imminent judgment
It is used for festive celebrations and harvest festivals
It represents the voice of the prophets in public assemblies
It is a musical instrument for worship in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It signals a call to battle or warning of imminent judgment
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:1 uses the trumpet as a symbol to warn of coming judgment, akin to ancient Near Eastern practices where trumpets announced war or calamity.

questions.question: In Hosea 8:4, what is the theological implication of Israel setting up kings 'not by me'?
options: Their leadership lacks divine sanction and is therefore illegitimate
They are following God's appointed kings exclusively
Their kings are chosen by popular vote and are accountable to God
They are establishing a theocracy led by priests
questions.correctAnswer: Their leadership lacks divine sanction and is therefore illegitimate
questions.explanation: The verse indicates Israel’s kings were set up without God's approval, highlighting illegitimacy and disobedience to the covenant.

questions.question: Hosea 8:7 states, 'they have sown the wind, and they shall reap the whirlwind.' What type of literary device is this?
options: Simile comparing Israel to the wind
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor illustrating consequences of actions
questions.explanation: This metaphor describes how Israel's reckless actions will result in severe consequences, a common prophetic device.

questions.question: Which ancient empire is referenced in Hosea 8:9 as having been approached by Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Assyria
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:9 refers to Assyria as the foreign power Israel has turned to, reflecting historical alliances and political reliance.

questions.question: How does Hosea 8:12 describe Israel's reaction to the 'great things of my law'?
options: They regarded them as strange things
They wrote them on their hearts
They taught them to their children
questions.correctAnswer: They regarded them as strange things
questions.explanation: The peoples’ rejection of God's law as 'strange' reveals their alienation and rebellion against covenantal obligations.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Hosea 8:6, the calf of Samaria is not God because it was ______.
questions.correctAnswer: made by the workman
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes the idol's human origin, distinguishing it from the true God who is uncreated.

questions.question: What is the consequence for Israel in Hosea 8:8 as they are 'swallowed up'?
options: They become among the Gentiles as a vessel with no pleasure
They are exalted above other nations
They enter into a new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: They become among the Gentiles as a vessel with no pleasure
questions.explanation: The verse conveys Israel's loss of favor and status, becoming despised among the nations.

questions.question: Which theme is foreshadowed by the phrase 'return to Egypt' in Hosea 8:13?
options: Physical return to the Promised Land
questions.correctAnswer: Exile and punishment for disobedience
questions.explanation: Returning to Egypt symbolizes regression and punishment, recalling Israel’s slavery and captivity.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 8:14 states that Judah's strategy for security was building many fenced cities.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly notes Judah multiplied fenced cities as a defensive measure.

questions.question: According to Hosea 8:11, what is the ironic result of Ephraim making many altars to sin?
options: Altars shall be unto him to sin
They will have peace with neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: Altars shall be unto him to sin
questions.explanation: The altars intended for worship become occasions for sin, highlighting the futility of their idolatry.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'they have sown the wind' in Hosea 8:7 imply about Israel's actions?
options: They engaged in futile or reckless actions that will yield destructive results
They planted crops that failed to grow
They spread the word of God among the nations
They built strong alliances with neighboring countries
questions.correctAnswer: They engaged in futile or reckless actions that will yield destructive results
questions.explanation: The metaphor conveys that their deeds are empty and will provoke harsh consequences.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the cultural significance of making idols from silver and gold as mentioned in Hosea 8:4?
options: It reflects syncretism and reliance on material wealth instead of God
It is a traditional Israelite worship practice
It symbolizes the purity and holiness of God
It is a method to honor the true God
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects syncretism and reliance on material wealth instead of God
questions.explanation: The verse criticizes Israel for crafting gods from precious metals, showing misplaced trust in material idols.

questions.question: How does Hosea 8:3's statement 'Israel hath cast off the thing that is good' connect to broader biblical themes?
options: It echoes the theme of rejecting divine covenant blessings resulting in pursuit by enemies
It celebrates Israel's new covenant relationship
It highlights Israel's wisdom in political alliances
It praises Israel's faithfulness to God
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the theme of rejecting divine covenant blessings resulting in pursuit by enemies
questions.explanation: This reflects the biblical motif that forsaking God's goodness leads to vulnerability and judgment.

questions.question: What is the literary function of the parallelism between 'Israel hath forgotten his Maker' and 'buildeth temples' in Hosea 8:14?
options: To contrast true worship with false security measures
To describe the geography of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: To contrast true worship with false security measures
questions.explanation: The parallelism highlights Israel's spiritual negligence contrasted with superficial efforts at protection.

questions.question: What historical insight is gained from Hosea 8:9's depiction of Ephraim as a 'wild ass alone by himself'?
options: It illustrates Israel's political isolation and instability
It indicates their strength and unity
It shows their alliance with Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates Israel's political isolation and instability
questions.explanation: The simile conveys Ephraim's solitary and erratic political behavior in contrast to stable alliances.

theological.title: Hosea Chapter 8 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hosea Chapter 8 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Hosea 8:1 for the coming of one like an eagle against the house of the LORD?
options: They have transgressed God's covenant and law
They have built many altars to sin
questions.correctAnswer: They have transgressed God's covenant and law
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:1 states the eagle comes against the house of the LORD because they have transgressed the covenant and trespassed against God's law. This theme is consistent with Deuteronomy 28:15-68 where covenant disobedience leads to judgment, Jeremiah 11:10 about breaking covenant, and New Testament passages like Hebrews 8:9 referencing Israel's covenant breach.

questions.question: According to Hosea 8:3, what consequence does Israel face after casting off what is good?
options: They shall prosper in the land
questions.correctAnswer: The enemy shall pursue him
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:3 warns that Israel casting off what is good results in the enemy pursuing them. This principle of reaping consequences for rejecting God is echoed in Galatians 6:7, Proverbs 22:8, and Judges 2:14.

questions.question: In Hosea 8:4, what is said about the kings and princes Israel set up?
options: They were not established by God and made from silver and gold idols
They were righteous and led Israel in God's ways
They were chosen by the LORD through prophets
They were foreign rulers imposed by Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: They were not established by God and made from silver and gold idols
questions.explanation: Verse 4 indicates Israel set up kings and princes not by God, making them from silver and gold idols, which results in their being cut off. This reveals human rebellion against divine sovereignty (1 Samuel 8:7-8; Isaiah 2:8; Jeremiah 10:5).

questions.question: Hosea 8:6 declares that the calf of Samaria is not God because:
options: It was made by a workman
It was hidden in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It was made by a workman
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:6 clarifies that the calf is not God because it is a human-made idol, not divine. This aligns with Exodus 20:4-5 forbidding graven images, Isaiah 44:9-20 showing idols are man-made and powerless, and Psalm 115:4-8 confirming idols cannot save.

questions.question: What does Hosea 8:7 mean by saying 'they have sown the wind, and they shall reap the whirlwind'?
options: Their sinful actions will lead to severe consequences
They will be protected from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Their sinful actions will lead to severe consequences
questions.explanation: This metaphor in Hosea 8:7 indicates that Israel’s actions (sowing the wind) will result in greater judgment (reaping the whirlwind). This principle is echoed in Galatians 6:7, Job 4:8, and Hosea 10:13, emphasizing divine justice.

questions.question: According to Hosea 8:9, what is Ephraim compared to, and what does this imply about Israel's alliances?
options: A wild ass alone, implying unreliable and solitary alliances
A mighty lion, implying strength in alliances
questions.correctAnswer: A wild ass alone, implying unreliable and solitary alliances
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:9 compares Ephraim to a wild ass by himself, highlighting the folly and instability of his foreign alliances (hiring lovers). This imagery parallels Isaiah 1:3 and Jeremiah 2:24, illustrating Israel’s stubbornness and isolation despite alliances.

questions.question: What does Hosea 8:11 teach about the altars Ephraim has made?
options: They have made many altars to sin, which will become altars for sin
They have made altars pleasing to God
They have made altars only for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They have made many altars to sin, which will become altars for sin
questions.explanation: Verse 11 reveals Ephraim’s many altars are for sin, and these altars themselves become instruments of sin and judgment. This reflects the idea in Leviticus 10:1-2 and 2 Chronicles 28:3 where improper worship leads to judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hosea 8:12 says, 'I have written to him the great things of my _______, but they were counted as a strange thing.'
questions.correctAnswer: law
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:12 states God wrote the great things of His law to Israel, but they regarded it as strange. This illustrates Israel’s rejection of divine revelation, consistent with Jeremiah 6:10, Isaiah 1:2-4, and Hebrews 8:7-9.

questions.question: Why does Hosea 8:13 say the LORD will not accept Israel's sacrifices and offerings?
options: Because Israel has sinned and the LORD will remember their iniquity
Because the sacrifices were not from the best animals
Because the offerings were made in foreign lands
questions.correctAnswer: Because Israel has sinned and the LORD will remember their iniquity
questions.explanation: The verse indicates that despite sacrifices, God rejects them due to Israel's sinfulness, and He will remember their iniquity, leading to judgment. This reflects themes in Isaiah 1:11-17, Psalm 51:16-17, and Hosea 6:6 about the heart of true worship.

questions.question: What consequence is foretold in Hosea 8:13 for Israel's sins?
options: They shall be exiled to Babylon
They shall be destroyed by fire
They shall be blessed with peace
questions.correctAnswer: They shall return to Egypt
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:13 prophesies that Israel’s sins will cause them to return to Egypt, symbolizing regression into bondage and judgment. This recalls the Exodus narrative and prophetic warnings in Jeremiah 42:14 and Ezekiel 20:6.

questions.question: What does Hosea 8:14 say Israel has forgotten, leading to God's judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Their Maker
questions.explanation: Verse 14 states Israel forgot their Maker, causing them to build temples and walls in vain, provoking God's judgment by fire. This theme is central in Psalm 100:3, Isaiah 5:4, and Jeremiah 18:15 about forgetting God leading to destruction.

questions.question: How does Hosea 8:2 depict Israel's acknowledgment of God?
options: They cry, 'My God, we know thee'
questions.correctAnswer: They cry, 'My God, we know thee'
questions.explanation: In Hosea 8:2, Israel claims to know God, reflecting superficial profession without true obedience. This is comparable to Matthew 7:21-23, Isaiah 29:13, and Jeremiah 7:9-10 where mere profession without heart obedience is condemned.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'calf of Samaria' in Hosea 8:5-6?
options: It is an idol made by human hands, not God
It is the true God of Israel
It symbolizes God's covenant with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It is an idol made by human hands, not God
questions.explanation: The calf of Samaria represents a man-made idol, rejected by God, emphasizing idolatry's futility (Hosea 8:5-6). This is consistent with Exodus 32:4-8, 1 Kings 12:28-30, and Psalms 106:19-20.

questions.question: What does Hosea 8:10 indicate about the nations Israel sought help from?
options: Though they hired help, God will gather them and they will sorrow
The nations will save Israel permanently
Israel's alliances will bring peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Though they hired help, God will gather them and they will sorrow
questions.explanation: Verse 10 foretells that despite Israel’s alliances, God will gather them for judgment and they will mourn their burden. This reflects Isaiah 31:1, Jeremiah 2:18, and Habakkuk 1:9 on misplaced trust in nations.

questions.question: In Hosea 8:8, how is Israel described among the Gentiles?
options: As a vessel wherein there is no pleasure
As a mighty nation honored by all
questions.correctAnswer: As a vessel wherein there is no pleasure
questions.explanation: Hosea 8:8 conveys Israel will be despised and unpleasing among the Gentiles, indicating judgment and loss of blessing. This corresponds with Isaiah 2:6, Ezekiel 36:19, and Romans 11:11 about Israel’s partial hardening and dispersion.
